title: Lucy Borkowski
text:
I’m Lucy Borkowski, a fourth year undergraduate Statistics & Data Science student at UCLA. I’m passionate about statistical modeling, computational methods, and using data to understand real-world problems. Through my coursework and projects, I’ve gained experience in regression, linear models, simulation, optimization, and statistical programming in both R and C++.
Outside of academics, I’m involved in Bruin Belles and BruinXR, where I’ve had the chance to take on leadership and outreach roles. I also love traveling, playing soccer, exploring new languages, and finding ways to make a positive impact in my community.
Download my CV/Resume here: CV/Resume

title: Lucy Borkowski
text:
Experience
LoanCore Capital — Commercial Real Estate Finance Intern
Los Angeles, CA | June 2025 – August 2025
I analyzed financial and market data to evaluate commercial real estate loan risk, supported underwriting and due diligence, built financial models in Excel, and contributed to market and comparable-property research.
Meals on Wheels — Director’s Office Intern
Raleigh, NC | August 2021 – June 2022
I supported the Director by coordinating administrative tasks, managing documentation, and ensuring that time-sensitive projects were completed accurately and efficiently. I also worked closely with the accounting department, assisting with financial documentation, data organization, and other administrative tasks to ensure accuracy and timely completion of projects.

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the United States, affecting millions each year:

1 in 5 Americans will develop skin cancer by age 70

Over 2 people die every hour from skin cancer in the U.S.

Early detection of melanoma greatly increases survival

Risk assessment is challenging manually; machine learning can improve prediction by detecting complex patterns in data

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the United States, affecting millions each year:

1 in 5 Americans will develop skin cancer by age 70

Over 2 people die every hour from skin cancer in the U.S.

Early detection of melanoma greatly increases survival

Risk assessment is challenging manually; machine learning can improve prediction by detecting complex patterns in data

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Data & Cleaning

Training data: 50,000 rows, 50 columns

Testing data: 20,000 rows, 49 predictors

Cancer distribution (training): Benign 47.7%, Malignant 52.3%

Baseline accuracy: 52.26%

Predictor types: 49 predictors: 18 numeric, 31 categorical (some numeric represent categories, e.g., outdoor_job, zip_code_last_digit)


Missing Data

Training: 196,042 missing values (7.84%)

Testing: 78,256 missing values (7.99%)

Missingness spread evenly; no predictor >10% missing

Imputation methods compared: missForest, MICE, median/mode replacement

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Methodology

Explored multiple approaches: LASSO, Elastic Net, stepwise regression, subset selection

Multiple imputation methods tested for missing data

Median-mode imputation selected for final model due to stability

Focused on statistically significant predictors for final model

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Models

Random Forest
Full model:
- Used all 49 predictors
- Training confusion matrix showed Benign error 51%, Malignant error 33%
- Tended to classify Malignant better than Benign
- Kaggle testing accuracy: 59.835%
Reduced 15-predictor model:
- Selected top 15 important predictors
- Training confusion matrix: Benign error 55%, Malignant error 35%
- Performance worse than full model
- Important features included Age, UV exposure, and Occupation


Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM)

Bernoulli loss for binary classification

Hyperparameters tuned:

of trees: 8,000
Interaction depth: 5

Shrinkage: 0.005

Min observations per node: 10

Subsample: 1.0


10-fold CV to select optimal # of trees (~2042 trees)

Training accuracy: ~60.415% on Kaggle

Observed overfitting when too many trees were used



Final Model – Logistic Regression

Selected statistically significant predictors (18 total):

Demographics/Environment: Age, Urban_Rural, Years_Lived_At_Address, Skin_Tone

Behavioral/Protective: Hat_Use, Tanning_Bed_Use, Clothing_Protection, Sun_Burns_Last_Year

Medical Risk Factors: Family_History, Immunosuppressed, Skin_Photosensitivity

Lesion-specific: Lesion_Location, Number_Of_Lesions

Misc: Music_Genre


Training accuracy: 60.76%

Kaggle testing accuracy: 60.545%

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Results / Limitations

Logistic regression improved baseline by ~8%

Advantages: Simplicity, interpretability, moderate accuracy

Limitations:

Median/mode imputation may introduce bias

GBM and Random Forest are computationally expensive

Models may overfit if not properly tuned

Logistic regression struggles with non-linear relationships and multicollinearity

Random seed and train/test split affect reproducibility

Some predictors may appear insignificant due to modeling choices

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Discussion

Real-world application: Current models are not clinically reliable (<70% accuracy)

Dermatology screening tools achieve >90% accuracy

Logistic regression selected as final model for interpretability

Random Forest and GBM slightly worse or similar in performance, more complex to interpret

Provides baseline for future research, feature engineering, and model tuning

title: Project 3 – Predicting Skin Cancer Status
text:
Conclusion

Best model accuracy: ~60.545%

Logistic regression with 18 significant predictors chosen for final model

Model simplicity and interpretability are key advantages

Further improvements require richer clinical data, imaging, and medically informed predictors

Serves as a solid baseline for future predictive modeling in skin cancer research

Presentation of the project here: 101C Project

title: Project 1 – Predicting Life Expectancy
text: This project develops a statistical modeling framework to quantify how key socioeconomic and well-being indicators influence healthy life expectancy across countries. Using international data from the Gallup World Poll, sourced through the World Happiness Report (143 observations), the analysis investigates whether happiness levels, economic conditions, and perceived government corruption can serve as reliable predictors of population health outcomes.

title: Project 1 – Predicting Life Expectancy
text: This project develops a statistical modeling framework to quantify how key socioeconomic and well-being indicators influence healthy life expectancy across countries. Using international data from the Gallup World Poll, sourced through the World Happiness Report (143 observations), the analysis investigates whether happiness levels, economic conditions, and perceived government corruption can serve as reliable predictors of population health outcomes.

title: Project 1 – Predicting Life Expectancy
text:
Technical Approach
We implemented a multiple linear regression framework to model healthy life expectancy as a function of three predictors:

Happiness Score (1–10)

Economic Well-Being (GDP per capita index)

Perceptions of Corruption (public trust metric)

Initial exploratory analysis showed positive correlations between life expectancy and both happiness and GDP per capita, while corruption showed no meaningful linear relationship. Skewness and several influential observations motivated a transformation-based modeling approach.
To address violations of normality and heteroscedasticity, we applied Box–Cox power transformations to the response and predictors. Model diagnostics indicated that individualized transformations significantly improved fit. Variable-selection procedures (Adjusted R², AIC/AICc, BIC, and added-variable plots) identified perceptions of corruption as a non-significant predictor and it was removed from the final specification.

title: Project 1 – Predicting Life Expectancy
text:
Final Model
The optimized model estimates transformed healthy life expectancy as a function of transformed GDP per capita and happiness score:
[ ()^{1.43} = -0.0087 + 0.235 ()^2 + 0.038 ()^2 ]
The final model explains 72.35% of the variance in healthy life expectancy ((R^2 = 0.7235)) and is statistically significant (ANOVA (p < 0.05)). Both remaining predictors show strong statistical significance and positive effects.

title: Project 1 – Predicting Life Expectancy
text:
Key Findings

Economic prosperity and subjective well-being are strong, quantifiable drivers of healthy life expectancy.

Perceived corruption does not meaningfully predict life expectancy within this dataset.

The results highlight potential policy levers — improvements in economic conditions and well-being metrics may translate into measurable health gains.

title: Project 1 – Predicting Life Expectancy
text:
Limitations & Future Work

The study notes potential omitted-variable bias, sensitivity to outliers, and limited generalizability due to the concentration of upper-middle-income countries in the dataset.

Future extensions include expanding the feature set, applying the model to additional years, and validating performance across more diverse global populations.

Presentation of the project here: 101A Project

title: Project 2 – The Effects of Age, Gender, and Exercise Type on Physiological Stress Markers in Islander Populations
text:
This study investigates how biological stress responses vary by type of physical activity, and whether these responses are moderated by age and gender in an Islander population. Key questions include:

Are there gender differences in physical endurance?

Does age correlate with physical endurance in high-exertion tasks (e.g., swimming)?

Are elevated blood hormone (adrenaline and cortisol) levels associated with increased physical activity?

Does type of physical activity influence stress hormone responses?

title: Project 2 – The Effects of Age, Gender, and Exercise Type on Physiological Stress Markers in Islander Populations
text:
This study investigates how biological stress responses vary by type of physical activity, and whether these responses are moderated by age and gender in an Islander population. Key questions include:

Are there gender differences in physical endurance?

Does age correlate with physical endurance in high-exertion tasks (e.g., swimming)?

Are elevated blood hormone (adrenaline and cortisol) levels associated with increased physical activity?

Does type of physical activity influence stress hormone responses?

title: Project 2 – The Effects of Age, Gender, and Exercise Type on Physiological Stress Markers in Islander Populations
text:
Background & Existing Literature

Cortisol and Adrenaline as Coordinated Stress Hormones: Cortisol regulates energy metabolism, immune function, and exercise adaptation, while adrenaline supports immediate energy and cardiovascular output (Hackney & Walz, 2013).

Exercise Intensity and Cortisol Response: Moderate to high intensity exercise (≥60% VO2 max) significantly elevates cortisol; low-intensity exercise (≈40%) produces minimal hormonal response (Hill et al., 2008).

Physical Activity and Hormonal Health: Regular exercise reduces cortisol and improves sleep quality; most research is clinical, focusing on women with health conditions (De Nys et al., 2022).

Age-Related Decline in Physical Activity: Physical activity decreases by 40–80% with age, increasing chronic disease risk and altering stress hormone responses (Suryadinata et al., 2020).

Gender Differences in Endurance: Men generally have higher VO2max, while women excel in pacing, fat utilization, and fatigue resistance (Besson et al., 2022).

title: Project 2 – The Effects of Age, Gender, and Exercise Type on Physiological Stress Markers in Islander Populations
text:
Methods

Participants

N = 90 healthy individuals from the Islander population

Balanced by gender (45 males, 45 females) and age groups (0–25, 26–50, 51+)



Experimental Design

Open-label, three-way between-subjects factorial design

Independent Variables:

Exercise Type: Bungee Jumping, Swimming, Light Jogging

Age Group: 0–25, 26–50, 51+

Gender: Male, Female


Dependent Variables:

Change in adrenaline, cortisol, and blood oxygen levels (post-pre)


18 total groups (2 genders × 3 age groups × 3 activities)

5 participants per group to maintain balanced design



Procedure

Participants completed one of the three exercises

Blood samples collected before and after exercise

Physiological changes computed for stress markers and oxygen levels



Sample Size Determination

Power = 0.80, α = 0.05, effect size = 0.40

Minimum N = 74 (G*Power)

Final N = 90 to ensure balanced groups and independence



Data Analysis

Three-way ANOVA to assess main effects and interactions of Exercise Type, Age, and Gender

Post-hoc comparisons via Tukey HSD

Visual diagnostics with Residual and Q-Q plots

title: Project 2 – The Effects of Age, Gender, and Exercise Type on Physiological Stress Markers in Islander Populations
text:
Results

ANOVA & MANOVA

Gender significantly influenced stress responses:

Adrenaline change (p = 0.002)

Cortisol change (p = 0.036)


Age effects were not significant

Age × Gender interaction not significant

Blood oxygen levels remained stable across groups



Post-Hoc Analysis

Tukey HSD: Significant gender differences in adrenaline levels (p = 0.002)

Females exhibited higher post-swimming adrenaline, especially in age groups 0–25 and 51+



Diagnostics

Residual and Q-Q plots indicated model assumptions largely met

No major violations observed

title: Project 2 – The Effects of Age, Gender, and Exercise Type on Physiological Stress Markers in Islander Populations
text:
Conclusions

Gender is a stronger determinant of physiological stress response than age in high-exertion activities

Swimming elicited higher adrenaline responses in females across age groups

Age does not significantly modify cortisol, adrenaline, or oxygen response in this population

High-intensity exercise in Islander populations highlights gender-specific adaptations in stress physiology

Presentation of the project here: 101B Project

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Hurricanes form over warm ocean waters when heat and moisture cause rising air, creating low pressure. As air continues to rise and rotate, storms intensify.

Lower central pressure → stronger winds

Hurricanes are ranked Category 1–5 based on sustained wind speed

Predicting which storms will become major hurricanes (Category 3–5) is crucial for emergency planning and saving lives

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Hurricanes form over warm ocean waters when heat and moisture cause rising air, creating low pressure. As air continues to rise and rotate, storms intensify.

Lower central pressure → stronger winds

Hurricanes are ranked Category 1–5 based on sustained wind speed

Predicting which storms will become major hurricanes (Category 3–5) is crucial for emergency planning and saving lives

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Research Question
To what extent can early meteorological measurements—wind speed, central pressure, and storm location—predict whether a tropical hurricane will intensify into a major hurricane?
- Which variables are most significant in category prediction?

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Data & Methodology

Important Variables

Pressure: Lower central pressure indicates stronger storm

Wind Speed: Direct measure of intensity

Track Coordinates (latitude/longitude): Storm behavior differs by region

Date: Seasonal cycles influence intensity

Category: Classification based on maximum sustained wind

Naming Status: Named storms often reach higher intensity and are monitored more closely



Data Cleaning

Started with ~13,665 storm observations

Removed missing or impossible values (e.g., pressure = 0, wind = 0)

Feature engineered:

category from max wind

region from coordinates

hemisphere from storm ID


Final cleaned dataset: ~12,674 observations

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Initial Exploratory Analysis

Visualized distributions of pressure, wind speed, and category

Explored spatial patterns across latitudes and regions

Examined seasonal trends in intensification

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Modeling

Model 1: Logistic Regression (Main Effects)

Predictors: wind speed, pressure, latitude, longitude, region

AIC: 12,435; AUC: 0.797

Threshold 0.5: major hurricane classification ~48%, non-major ~92.7%

Optimal threshold from ROC = 0.336 → balanced accuracy = 0.712

Key insights: Lower pressure & higher wind early → higher odds of major hurricane

Limitation: Under-predicts major hurricanes → nonlinear/interaction effects missed



Model 2: Logistic Regression with Interaction Terms

Added interactions: wind × pressure, wind × latitude

AIC dropped to 12,138; AUC = 0.8055

Optimal threshold = 0.3091

Major hurricane classification improved from 64% → 67%

Balanced accuracy = 0.731

Key takeaway: Interactions capture conditional meteorological effects



Model 3: Random Forest

Predictors: wind speed, pressure, latitude, longitude, region

Motivation: Capture nonlinear patterns & complex interactions missed by logistic regression

Classification performance:

Major hurricanes: 81.8%

Non-major: 85%


AUC = 0.911 → substantial improvement over logistic regression



Model 4: Random Forest with Interaction Features

Added engineered interactions from logistic regression Model 2

Captured complex conditional effects

Performance:

Major hurricanes: 76.6%

Non-major: 85.8%

AUC = 0.8994 (slightly lower than simpler RF)


RF already incorporates interactions → added terms slightly redundant

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Results & Analysis

Best performing model: Random Forest (Model 3)

Most influential predictors:

Wind speed (high wind → higher intensification odds)

Central pressure (low pressure → higher intensification odds)


Predictive accuracy: ~82% for major hurricanes

AUC: 0.91 → model reliably separates major vs non-major hurricanes

Early meteorological measurements can predict major hurricane potential with strong confidence

title: Project 4 – Predicting Hurricane Behavior: Meteorological, Spatial, and Temporal Predictors
text:
Feature & Model Limitations

Some meteorological factors (e.g., sea surface temperature, humidity) unavailable

Older storm data may be less accurate due to technological limitations

Class imbalance: major hurricanes less common → potential skew in models

Data cleaning may introduce selection bias (removing missing/impossible values)

Logistic regression struggled with nonlin
